item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: cultum-admin
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Suggested text: Our website address is: https://cultum.gr.

Comments

Suggested text: When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

Suggested text: If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Cookies

Suggested text: If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Suggested text: Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Who we share your data with

Suggested text: If you request a password reset, your IP address will be included in the reset email.

How long we retain your data

Suggested text: If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

Suggested text: If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where your data is sent

Suggested text: Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

item.title: Athens: The home of Democracy
item.dc:creator: cultum-admin
item.content:encoded:
[vc_row][vc_column][vc_empty_space height="50px"][vc_column_text css="" css_animation="bottom-to-top"]

Athens was the first ever elected European Capital of Culture

[/vc_column_text][vc_empty_space height="50px"][vc_column_text css="" css_animation="bottom-to-top"]Athens became the first European Capital of Culture in 1985, marking the beginning of a prestigious initiative designed to celebrate the diverse cultural heritage of European cities. Spearheaded by Melina Mercouri, the Greek Minister of Culture, and her French counterpart Jack Lang, the program aimed to foster a sense of shared European identity through cultural expression and collaboration. The selection of Athens was a nod to the city's historical importance as the birthplace of democracy, philosophy, and the arts, highlighting its role as a beacon of cultural influence throughout history (Melina Mercouri Foundation) (Wikipedia). The cultural events in Athens included a wide range of performances, exhibitions, and artistic endeavors that celebrated both the citys ancient legacy and its vibrant contemporary culture. Internationally acclaimed artists such as Leonard Bernstein, Ingmar Bergman, and Mstislav Rostropovich participated in these events, drawing global attention to Athens (Melina Mercouri Foundation) (Europeana). The citys historic sites, including the Acropolis and the Odeon of Herodes Atticus, served as iconic venues for concerts and performances, reinforcing the city's image as a cultural and historical center. Athens' tenure as the first European Capital of Culture set a precedent for future cities, demonstrating the potential for cultural initiatives to enhance tourism, foster community pride, and create lasting cultural legacies. The success of the program in Athens paved the way for other cities to explore and celebrate their own unique cultural identities, promoting cultural exchange and understanding across Europe (Melina Mercouri Foundation) (Europeana). Today, Athens continues to be celebrated for its rich cultural offerings, with the legacy of 1985 inspiring ongoing cultural development and innovation (Europeana) (Wikipedia).[/vc_column_text][vc_empty_space height="50px"][gem_gallery source_type="custom" metro_max_row_height="380" gallery_hover="zooming-blur" title_show="" description_show="" gallery_gallery="25635" autoscroll="5000"][vc_empty_space height="50px"][gem_button text="Back to blog page" position="center" corner="3" icon_pack="elegant" link="url:https%3A%2F%2Fcultum.gr%2Fblog%2F|title:Blog" icon_elegant="e08d"][vc_empty_space][/vc_column][/vc_row]
item.excerpt:encoded: Athens became the first European Capital of Culture in 1985, marking the beginning of a prestigious initiative designed to celebrate the diverse cultural heritage of European cities.

item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: cultum-admin
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Description: Embark on an interactive adventure across Athens, utilizing a diverse set of H5P sub-content types to explore seven iconic locations. Each spot offers unique educational activities that highlight the rich cultural tapestry of Athens. [h5p id="2"]

Description: After taking notes of all the important historic treasures you found in Monastiraki square, you decide to get lost in the valleys of Athens. Suddenly, you spot a mysterious box outside of an abandoned shop. You open it and you find out that the box contains 7 tarot cards, which seem to have a magical aura. Test your knowledge of Athenian culture with these cards, by answering to 7 different questions on topics from the previous levels. Don't give up now, you're almost there! Objective: Answer correctly to all 7 questions based on the previous levels, to finish your exploration of Athens. [h5p id="16"]

Description: Test your knowledge of Athenian culture with this exploration overview, answering 8 different questions on topics from the previous levels. Objective: Answer correctly to all 8 questions to finish your exploration of Athens. [h5p id="16"]

Description: Next, you arrive at the high building Manolis told you about, which has the perfect view to Monastiraki square. Can you spot the historic treasures among the crowd? Search through your point of view, identify and click on cultural elements hidden within this aerial view of Monastiraki Square. Objective: Spot and click on all of the structures of great cultural importance. Tip: Not all structures are located on Monastiraki Square, they could also be in any other visible area. [h5p id="18"]

Description: Having gathered historical insights from Exarchia, use them to unlock a chest full of Athenian treasures in Thiseio. This level combines historical knowledge with the thrill of discovery. Objective: Input the historical code to access and learn about ancient artifacts, connecting them to the stories uncovered so far. [h5p id="3"]

Description: In the upscale neighborhood of Kolonaki, assemble a complex jigsaw puzzle featuring the lush, serene views of the National Garden. Discover a hidden textual clue within the puzzle that connects Athens's verdant beauty with its rich musical heritage. Objective: Solve the puzzle to uncover the hidden message "Rebetiko" and prepare for a deeper exploration into Athenian music in the next level. [h5p id="8"]

Description: Now in the bohemian district of Psirri, engage with a memory card game to delve into the soulful sounds of Athenian music. Inspired by the clue from the previous puzzle, this game features traditional instruments and legendary Rebetiko songs. Objective: Match audio clips and images of traditional music elements to deepen your connection to Athens's rich musical tapestry and cultural heritage. [h5p id="14"]
